title: Understanding Arguments
summary: Recognize, classify, and evaluate everyday arguments—then improve them.

lessons.title: What is an Argument?
key_ideas: Argument = claim (conclusion) + reasons (premises) intended to persuade.
Conclusion vs premises: signal words like 'therefore/so' (conclusion) and 'because/since' (premises).
Not every statement or opinion is an argument—reasons must support a claim.
examples: Argument: "We should add bike lanes because crash rates drop where lanes exist."
Opinion (not an argument): "I hate bike lanes."
Argument: "It’s sunny, so we should go to the park."

quick_checks.question: Which of these is an argument?
choices: Since it’s sunny, we should go to the park.
feedback: This is a preference, not an argument.
Correct—reason (sunny) supports a conclusion (go to the park).

quick_checks.question: Identify the conclusion: "Crash rates drop where lanes exist, so we should add bike lanes."
choices: Crash rates drop where lanes exist.
feedback: Correct—this is the claim being argued for.

quick_checks.question: Which word most often signals a premise?

minigame.title: Spot the Argument
minigame.prompt: Look at this post: "Everyone should vote because democracy depends on participation." Is this an argument?
minigame.explanation: The reason 'democracy depends on participation' supports the conclusion 'everyone should vote'.

lessons.title: Two Roads—Deductive vs Inductive
key_ideas: Deductive: if premises are true, the conclusion must be true (aims at validity).
Inductive: if premises are true, the conclusion is likely true (degrees of support).
Why validity matters: deductive evaluation = validity; a sound argument is valid with true premises.
examples: Deductive: "All metals conduct. Copper is a metal. Therefore, copper conducts."
Inductive: "Every winter here has been rainy. This winter will likely be rainy."

quick_checks.question: Classify: "All mammals are warm-blooded. Whales are mammals. So whales are warm-blooded."
feedback: Correct—valid form if premises are true.
Inductive argues likelihood; this one claims certainty.

quick_checks.question: Classify: "The last 5 buses arrived late, so today’s bus will probably be late."
Which statement best describes 'soundness'?
choices: The argument is valid and the premises are true.
The argument is short and clear.
feedback: Clarity is good but not soundness.

minigame.title: Classifier Swipe
minigame.prompt:
Is the following argument deducTIVE or inducTIVE?
"Every time I water the plant it perks up; watering probably helps."
minigame.explanation: Uses past observations to support a probable conclusion.

lessons.title: Evaluating Arguments
key_ideas: Inductive: strength (how much support) & cogency (strong + true premises).
Defeasibility: new evidence can weaken a previously strong inductive argument.
examples: Valid but unsound: "All birds can fly. Penguins are birds. So penguins can fly." (false premise)
Strong but defeasible: "Most emails I get from this domain are scams; this new one might be a scam." (could be a legit email)

quick_checks.question: Label: "All squares are rectangles; all rectangles have four sides; therefore all squares have four sides."
Label: "It rained the last 8 days; it will rain tomorrow."
feedback: Deductive validity claims certainty; this is probabilistic.
Not the right label—this is an inductive argument.

quick_checks.question: Which edit strengthens this argument: "Electric cars are better because they’re modern."
choices: Add evidence on emissions and operating cost.

minigame.title: Repair the Argument
minigame.prompt: Pick the premise that best strengthens the claim: "We should open later on Mondays."
options: Customer data show 70% fewer visits before 10am on Mondays.
minigame.correct_option: Customer data show 70% fewer visits before 10am on Mondays.
minigame.explanation: Decision-relevant evidence makes the argument more cogent.

lessons.title: Common Misunderstandings
key_ideas: Evidence ≠ certainty: strong support still allows exceptions.
Opinion ≠ argument: reasons must support a claim.
Correlation ≠ causation: look for mechanisms and confounders.
examples: "You can’t prove this helps everyone, so it helps no one." (fallacy of perfection)
"Crime rose and ice cream sales rose—ice cream doesn’t cause crime." (confounder: temperature)

quick_checks.question: Fix the reasoning: "You can’t prove a seatbelt saves every life, so seatbelts are pointless."
choices: Ask for overall risk reduction evidence.
feedback: Perfection isn’t required for good policy.
Correct—look for aggregate outcomes and mechanisms.
We need reasons, not just opinions.

quick_checks.question: Which best addresses correlation ≠ causation?
choices: Find a plausible mechanism or run a controlled test.
Check if the correlation is surprising.
Ask if people like the result.

minigame.title: Myth-Buster
minigame.prompt: Claim: "This vitamin cured my cold; vitamins cure colds." What’s the best first move?
minigame.explanation: Controlled evidence helps separate correlation from causation.

lessons.title: Arguments in Context
key_ideas: Assumptions, definitions, and values shape arguments.
Emotions can add (motivate) or replace (distort) reasons.
Clarity first: define terms; make claims testable.
examples: Loaded definition: calling a tax a 'penalty' frames values.
Assumption: "Remote work hurts culture"—what counts as 'culture'?

quick_checks.question:
Which rewrite improves clarity?
Original: "This policy destroys freedom."
choices: This policy restricts protest permits after 10pm without appeal.

quick_checks.question: Spot the hidden assumption: "Ban smartphones in class to improve learning."
choices: All learning problems are caused by phones.
feedback: That can be true without justifying a ban.
Correct—this over-assumes causation; look for evidence.

minigame.title: X-Ray the Claim
minigame.prompt: Which assumption most likely underlies: "We should censor posts to reduce harm"?
options: All harmful posts are easy to identify.
Some content labeled 'harmful' may be context-dependent.
minigame.correct_option: All harmful posts are easy to identify.
minigame.explanation: Policies often assume detection is easy; testing that assumption changes the conclusion.

creator_challenge.title: Argument Map & Rewrite
creator_challenge.instructions: Find a recent post/article. 1) Extract the conclusion and premises. 2) List any assumptions/definitions. 3) Rewrite the claim for clarity and testability. Submit your map and rewrite.
